name: Mercury
facts: Mercury has the largest temperature differences between day and night in our solar system — over 500°C.
Mercury is slowly shrinking because its large iron core is contracting.

name: Venus
facts: Venus is the hottest planet due to its thick carbon dioxide atmosphere — temperatures reach up to 460°C.

name: Earth
facts: Earth is the only known planet with life.

name: Mars
facts: Mars hosts the tallest mountain in the solar system, Olympus Mons (27 km high).

name: Jupiter
facts: Jupiter is the largest planet and has the shortest days — only 9.8 hours.
Its Great Red Spot is a massive storm that's been raging for over 340 years.
It likely has the most moons, including Ganymede — the largest moon in the solar system.

name: Saturn
facts: Saturn has the most iconic ring system in the solar system.
Its moons are made largely of ice, and it experiences lightning a million times more powerful than Earth's.

name: Uranus
facts: Uranus has the most extreme seasons — the north pole points directly at the Sun during its summer.

name: Neptune
facts: Neptune is the farthest planet from the Sun.
It has the strongest winds in the solar system — over 2000 km/h.
Triton, one of its moons, has ice volcanoes that erupt nitrogen at -220°C.

name: Pluto
facts: Pluto (minor-planet designation: 134340 Pluto) is a dwarf planet in the Kuiper belt, a ring of bodies beyond the orbit of Neptune.
Originally considered a planet, its classification was changed when astronomers adopted a new definition of planet.

name: Earth's Moon
facts: The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite. In geophysical terms, the Moon is a planetary-mass object or satellite planet.
It orbits around Earth at an average distance of 384399 km. The Moon is tidally locked to Earth, always facing it with the same side.

name: Carina Nebula
facts: Nebulae are often star-forming regions, such as in the Pillars of Creation in the Eagle Nebula. In these regions, the formations of gas, dust, and other materials "clump" together to form denser regions, which attract further matter and eventually become dense enough to form stars.
